abstract.text: This article empirically investigates how the transition to a market economy affected the relationship between motherhood and labour force outcomes in Poland.
We estimate different probit models on two panel datasets covering a three-year period before the reform (1987-1989) and a three-year period afterwards (1994-1996).

Contrary to a priori expectations, our findings indicate that during transition young children were much less of a deterrent to the employment probability of their mother than they were before transition.

Introduction
In this article we investigate the role of motherhood in shaping the employment outcomes of Polish women before and during transition to a market economy.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A priori expectations, based on a few indisputable phenomena -the nearly universal female labour market participation in the pre-transition period, the rapid deterioration of child-care facilities during transition, and the increasing discrimination in the labour market against women who could become mothers -suggest that being a mother in transition Poland entailed greater difficulties in combining paid work and family responsibilities than before.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, we will show that employment was more responsive to motherhood before than during transition.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In our analysis we will investigate some explanations for this puzzling result and we will discuss the results in the final part of the article.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: There has been very little research on mothers' labour supply choices in transition economies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Fong and Lokshin (2000) examined how women's labour force activity depends on household child-care choices in Romania.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: They showed that after transition women's labour market activity was strongly affected by the presence of children and was highly responsive to the cost of child care.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Saget (1999) estimated a model of labour supply decisions of married women in Hungary to measure the impact of the number and age of children on women's labour supply (in addition to a host of women's characteristics, such as individual wages and a household's non-labour income).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Using post-transition data, she found that the presence of young children decreased the probability of a woman participating in the labour market, while the presence of teenagers had the opposite effect.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These studies suggest that, during transition, women and mothers in Central and Eastern European countries tended to display a labour market behaviour more and more similar to the one of women in Western economies.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In their study of participation behaviour of East German women after German unification, Bonin and Euwals (2002) examined precisely this issue.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: They wondered how the high unemployment rate and the change in public policies that followed transition impacted the high female labour market participation of the pre-transition period, and whether East German women will eventually adapt their behaviour to West German patterns, characterized by a much lower female employment rate.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: They found that labour force participation was negatively affected by the number of pre-school children, and that this negative effect increased over time after the unification.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, they do not use data from the period before the unification to estimate how different women's labour market behaviour was before 1990.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: To our knowledge no specific study exists for Poland and in particular no comparison of pre-and post-transition female labour market behaviour has ever been carried out.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this article we ask the following questions: was motherhood in Poland a significant constraint to women's employment during transition?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Was it the case before the transition?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In our analysis we use panel data for both periods (1987-1989 and 1994-1996) to disentangle the direct effect of children on female employment © 2009The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development from women's unobserved taste for children and employment, while controlling for relevant individual and household characteristics.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: We will argue, based on our results, that in the pre-transition period characterized by virtually no constraints to join the labour market (no unemployment, availability of child-care facilities), preferences -including cultural attitudes and social expectations about the role of mothers in a traditional society such as Poland -played a fundamental role in shaping mothers' employment patterns.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: On the other hand, during transition, the need for a second earner in the household, the great uncertainty in the labour market, and (for highly educated women) the new opportunities offered by a rapidly developing private sector were powerful reasons for mothers to be in employment, and be able to overcome the increasing difficulties represented by the deterioration of child-care facilities.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The article is structured as follows: Section 1 contains an Introduction with a sub-section to provide background information to describe the position of women in the Polish labour market, as well as the family policies existing in the pretransition period and during transition.

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Background

Before 1989, despite the high female labour market participation, the absence of unemployment, and the generous provision of maternity benefits and public child care, women were in a position of disadvantage in the labour market.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: In a patriarchal society such as Poland, women were expected to fulfil the role of main child-care providers.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: At the same time, women were also expected to work in remunerative employment, both for wages needed to support their family, and because women's labour was essential to the production system in a period of rapid industrialization (Nowakowska and Swêdrowska, 2000).
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: As Leven (2008) very effectively pointed out, gender equality was ideologically consistent with a socialist state and womenfriendly policies were mandated by a government that lacked popular support.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: Employed women were concentrated in low skilled and low paid occupations, despite being disproportionally highly educated.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: 2 Because supply of part-time jobs 2 It should be noted, however, that the pre-transition Poland had one of the lowest female activity rates of all Central and Eastern European countries.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: Around 1989, about 68 percent of women in 15 -54 years of age were participating in the labour force -a much lower percentage than, for example, in Czechoslovakia, the Baltic States, Belarus, Moldova, Russia, or Ukraine, all with more than 80 percent of female labour market participation.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: Still, women's activity rates were substantially higher in Poland than in most Western countries.
body_text.section: Background

body_text.text: More specifically, all women in the labour force were employed (unemployment being nonexistent in socialist countries) and almost all employed women were working full-time, given the negligible size of part-time employment (UNICEF, 1999).

body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: However, because women were the main ones responsible for child care and the secondary earners inside the family, they had to sustain the double burden of careers and family obligations (Ruminska-Zimny, 2002).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: During transition, activity rates dropped considerably, for both women and men.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Polish women experienced a dramatic drop in employment -about 900,000 jobs were lost by women from 1989 to 1995.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Unemployment, non-existent in the communist period, was 13 percent in 1997 for women of all ages, and 10 percent for men (UNICEF, 1999).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Transition hit women in particular, not just because women were more likely to lose their job and less likely to find one -thus becoming the majority of the long-term unemployed -but also because they were systematically discriminated against in the labour market (especially in the nascent private one).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: 3 While published statistics and empirical studies on Polish transition extensively document the changes in the social and economic position of women in general following the 1990 events, data on changes in the labour market participation of mothers are hard to find.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Some evidence exists on two adverse phenomena for mothers' position in the labour market in transition Poland -the rapid increase in women's discrimination in the private labour market and the substantial decrease in public child care provision.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Despite the fact that the cost of maternity leave was still fully covered by the social insurance system, employers in post-1990 Poland were reluctant to hire women who could become pregnant -either to avoid the hassle of finding a temporary replacement or due to the assumption that, once back to work after the childbearing period, mothers would become unenthusiastic workers with outdated skills (Lohmann and Seibert, 2003;World Bank, 2004).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: According to some studies, increasing discrimination in the private sector meant that women with children were disproportionately more likely to be out of work.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: A UNICEF study based on the Polish Labour Force Survey finds that 'Poland marriage status -a reliable proxy for the presence of children -was not a factor for unemployed men in finding work, but was a serious handicap for unemployed women' (UNICEF, 1999, p. 29).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: However, it should be noted that, according to the same study, the presence of children did not increase the chances of employed women losing jobs with respect to men, indicating that many women needed and were actually able to combine paid work and family commitments.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: As far as the decrease in public child-care provision is concerned, it is undeniable that child-care services were severely cut during transition (especially in kindergartens), and their fees increased considerably.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Nowakowska and Swêdrowska (2000) estimate that at the end of the 1990s the typical kindergarten fee could account for 30-45 percent of an average salary of a woman with a university diploma.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Some authors have stressed that, during transition, increasing costs of child care and demand-side factors were actually more important than the closure of child-care centres in explaining the decrease in enrolment rates.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: For example, Meurs and Giddings (2004) show that in the case of Bulgaria the drop in fertility rates, as well as the increase in unemployment rates and decrease in real wages -which accounted for a substantial decrease in disposable income and thus in the ability to pay for increasingly expensive child care -were the main drivers behind the decrease in enrolment rates.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: In Poland, some of the decrease in availability of state-subsidized child care can be explained by a drop in fertility, however the decreased supply of kindergartens and nurseries outweighed the drop in demand -the majority of kindergartens were full or above their capacity during transition (Lohmann and Seibert, 2003), although large geographical variations existed.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: In any case, it is unquestionable that the cost of raising a child increased substantially, as did the conflict between women's family duties and professional careers (Lohmann and Seibert, 2003).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: 4 The lack of adequate and affordable child-care services together with labour market discrimination could have 'encouraged' women to drop out of the labour force to raise children.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: On the other hand, women's dependency on their spouses' and other family members' income as well as their increased inability to return to paid work after long spells out of the labour force 5 were powerful reasons for mothers with a job to stay employed, even at the cost of exceptional efforts to juggle work and family responsibilities.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: 6 Which of the above contrasting forces prevailed in shaping employment opportunities for mothers during transition is an open question.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: In addition, it is unclear whether having children affected women's participation in the labour market more during transition than in the pre-transition period.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: We will explore these issues in the current analysis.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: 4 It should be stressed that, while child-care provision suffered substantial cuts during transition, the duration of maternity leave and the amount of maternity benefits were maintained at the pre-transition levels.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Mothers were paid a basic maternity benefit corresponding to 100 percent wage replacement for 16, 18, or 26 weeks after delivery (of the first child, any subsequent children, or in case of multiple births, respectively) and, if employed, were entitled to unpaid parental leave until the third birthday of the child, while retaining the right to their previous job (Golinowska et al. , 2003).

body_text.text: Until 1996, the last year of our sample data, these provisions remained unchanged, and are therefore not responsible for changes in women's labour supply which we may observe between the two periods.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Overall, means-tested and insurance-based family benefits characterized Poland as one of the least generous countries in the pre-transition Central and Eastern Europe (Fodor et al. , 2002).

Data
To answer these questions we use the panel data for Poland available in the Panel Comparability Project (PACO) -the original source is the Polish Household Panel (PHP) survey.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: 7 PACO is an international comparative database provided by CEPS/ INSTEAD (based in Luxembourg) integrating micro-data from various national household panels over a large number of years.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: 8 For Poland, the available data consist of two separate panels: the first includes four waves from 1987 to 1990, the second includes three waves from 1994 to 1996.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: Although the individuals observed are not the same in the pre-and post-transition period, we can still exploit all the advantages of using panel data to estimate a model of mothers' employment and compare the results in the two periods.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: The main advantages of using the Polish datasets through PACO are the consistency of variable definition over time (the original variables have been standardized and codified according to standardized international classifications), and (potentially) the comparability of the results with other countries included in the database (Hungary, among transitional economies, and some West-European economies like Germany and the UK).
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: Moreover, in the case of Poland, PACO includes two panels, one covering the pre-reform period and the other covering the transition period -overall a relatively long time span that allows for comparisons before and after the reform.
body_text.section: Data

body_text.text: The data comprises extensive information on labour force and work history (employment status, professional status, working time, sector of employment), and includes a set of household-and individual-level income variables, education and family background variables, household composition and demographic characteristics of each individual, and territorial division.

body_text.text: Female labour supply and fertility in Poland
Using the Polish Household Panel in PACO we start by providing some stylized facts about the employment and fertility behaviour of Polish women.

body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: For women aged 16-44 years the employment rate dropped very little, on average from 69 percent in the first period to 67 percent in the second period.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: However, the employment rate of mothers varied substantially depending on the age of the youngest child; moreover, the patterns were quite different in the two periods.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: 11 During transition, the employment rate of mothers also increased with the age of the youngest child, but the differences were much less pronounced.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Thus, a higher percentage of mothers of a child aged 0-2 years were employed than before the transition -50 vs. 41 percent.

body_text.text: However, only 59 percent of mothers of a youngest child aged 3-5 years and 71 percent of mother of a youngest child aged 6-11 years were employed during transition (while the corresponding pre-transition figures were 68 and 79 percent).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: To some extent, the decline in labour market participation of mothers of pre-school children (3-5 years old) can be accounted for by the decline in statesubsidized child-care.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Children aged 3-5 years were much more likely to be in kindergarten before than during transition, and even before transition much more likely to be in child care than children aged 0 -2 years old.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The largest difference in the employment rate before and during transition existed for the group of women without dependent children, 87 vs. 73 percent.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: However, the surprising finding is the comparatively large percentage of mothers of children aged 0-2 years old who were employed during transition -larger than in the first period.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: These patterns suggest that there were substantial differences in the probability of women to be employed between the two periods that were unrelated to motherhood (as illustrated by the differences in employment rates for women without dependent children between the 1987-1989 and the 1994-1996 periods).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The stylized facts presented in Figure 1 also suggest that the presence and the age of children was a crucial element in explaining women's employment before transition rather than during transition.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: That is, during transition the female employment rate was much less responsive to the age of the youngest child than it was before transition.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: This is in contrast with the general notion of universal female labour market participation before transition (which, in the case of Poland, was less than universal) and the foreseeable negative impact on mothers' employment during transition due to the deterioration of child-care facilities, as well as the increased discrimination in the private labour market.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Figure 1 shows the employment rates of women by age of the youngest child but does not take into account the total fertility and the changes in fertility patterns between the two periods.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: It can be argued that fertility is endogenous to labour supply -in fact, fertility rates dropped during transition and postponement of marriage and childbearing became one of the strategies to decrease the conflict between family commitments and paid work (UNICEF, 1999;Lohmann and© 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development Siebert, 2003).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Therefore, the large differences in employment rates of mothers with children of different ages observed before the transition could have been driven by a total higher fertility.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: This is to say that the age of the youngest child heavily influenced the employment rate of the mother due to the presence of more siblings in the first period than in the second period.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Table 1 shows that, if there is some validity in this explanation, it is very limited.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The average number of children generally decreased between the two periods, but not dramatically so (the decrease in fertility patterns accelerated in the late 1990s, that is, after the period considered in this study).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: For example, the average number of children aged 0-2 years for each woman aged 16-44 years was not much lower in the second period when, as Figure 1 shows, the employment rates of mothers of these very young children was 8 percentage points higher in 1994-1996.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Moreover, Table 1 also shows that the difference in the average number of children between working and non-working women was lower in the second than in the first period for the children aged 0-2 and 3-5 years.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Therefore, the stylized facts presented in Figure 1 do not seem to be driven by dramatic changes in fertility behaviour.

body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Women with different education levels are likely to have different attitudes toward employment and were also affected differently by labour market changes during transition.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: In Table 2 we show the proportion of women in  Figure 1, both before and after transition, mothers had lower employment rates than non-mothers or mothers of children aged 18 years or older.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Moreover, the younger the age of the youngest child, the lower the employment rate of the mother.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: This pattern was common across education levels, although some important differences should be stressed.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: First, highly educated mothers (third level education) 12 had substantially higher employment rates than mothers of children of the same age but with lower educational qualifications in both periods.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Moreover, highly educated women re-entered employment when the child was still very young -the employment rates of highly educated mothers with a child aged 3-5 years was over 80 percent both before and after transition.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Second, the transition does not seem to have affected the employment rate of mothers as much as it affected the employment rate of non-mothers.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: While women with non-dependent or no children had substantially lower employment rates in the period 1994 -1996 than they had in the period 1987 -1989 at almost all educational qualifications, the employment rate of mothers was lower in the post-transition period but not by the same large amounts and in the case of mothers of children aged 0-2 years it actually increased during transition.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: An age effect is likely to drive this result -transition negatively affected older women more than it did younger women.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Third, women were differently affected by the drop in employment rates during transition depending on their educational qualifications.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Highly educated women (with third level education) who were mothers did not experience any drop in employment rates, while the employment rate of non-mothers of the same educational level decreased in the second period.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Women with lower educational qualifications (mothers and non-mothers), by contrast, generally experienced large drops in employment rates, the exception being the mothers of children aged 2 years and younger.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: It seems therefore that the education level was a key factor in explaining employment outcomes following transition, more than having or not having children.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Finally, Table 3 shows the employment rates of married women depending on the participation in employment of their partner.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Before transition -when the employment rate of men and women was very high -having a partner out of employment was associated with a very high employment participation of the wife, while women with a working partner were less likely to work.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: This could be due to a genuine effect of the husband's employment status on his wife's employment status (compatible with the added worker effect, as well as with the effect produced by an increase in the household non-earned income on the woman's labour supply).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Econometric modelling
The study of female labour supply and its correlation with the presence of young children has a long tradition in the applied econometric literature.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: Two exhaustive surveys are given by Browning (1992) and Nakamura and Nakamura (1992).
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: These articles review the main issues concerning the estimation of the effects of the presence of children on women's labour supply and examine some select studies on this topic.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: The vast majority of the empirical studies find a negative correlation between fertility and women's labour supply.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: However, the interpretation of this result must consider a number of issues.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: The existence of heterogeneity among women, differing in their fixed unobserved preferences for work and children, introduces selection effects that can bias 'genuine' effects.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: For example, it could be that women with a higher 'taste' for children are those with lower unobservable abilities and skills in the labour market.
body_text.section: Econometric modelling

body_text.text: In that case, it would be this selection effect to drive the observed association between a higher number of children and lower labour market participation, rather than a 'true' causal effect due to discrimination

body_text.text: But what other potential explanations that are not captured by our model can explain this finding?
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: There are essentially two categories of explanations that can be put forward at this point.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: A first possibility could be that there is some omitted variable from our regressions, and that this(these) variable(s) -correlated with being a mother of children of different age groups -is (are) the 'true' explanation(s) of mothers' labour supply either before or during transition or both.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: For example, an increase in part-time employment in the transition period could explain why mothers were more likely to be employed -availability of part-time employment usually mitigates the negative effect of children on women's labour supply.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Unfortunately we do not have information of whether employment was part-time or full-time, so we cannot control for this variable.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: However, there is evidence of no increase in part-time job opportunities in the second period; data provided by enterprises indicate instead that a slight drop in the share of part-time employment occurred, from about 10 percent before transition to 8.8 percent in 1998 (Kwiatkowski, Socha and Sztanderska, 2001).
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Also, we do not have information on women's earnings and other nonearned income.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: It is possible that during transition mothers were pressured to stay in employment (if they had a job) or to take up employment because of the powerful, negative income effect produced by the drop in real wages (theirs and their husband's).

The second type of explanation is that the coefficients of the children dummies are 'true' effects, that is they capture real preferences, attitudes, or individual or social constraints that cannot be incorporated into the regressions.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: We can think of reasons why mothers in the transition period may have had an incentive to remain in the labour market.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The change in the general economic environment represented by the transition to a market economy was characterized by tremendous adjustments and restructuring, high layoff rates and low re-employment rates.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The resulting uncertainty in the labour market could have represented a powerful incentive for women to work despite the presence of young children.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Moreover, in the first period, despite labour market constraints (including no unemployment) being much lower and women's labour market participation rate being higher, the traditional role of caregiver assigned to women represented a powerful disincentive for mothers of young children to join the labour market.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Finally, the two phenomena that lead us to expect a stronger disadvantage for mothers in the second period -increasing labour market discrimination and substantial cuts in child-care facilities -may have been overemphasized as far as their effects on the labour market participation of mothers of young children are concerned.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: Lohmann and Seibert (2003) report that, during transition, employers preferred women aged 25 -35 years over older women.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: The reasons for this preference probably being that younger women are better educated, better able to adapt to a free market economy, more likely to master ICTs and foreign languages, and also more physically attractive.
body_text.section: © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

body_text.text: That is, as much as employers may have disliked the possibility that these women could become mothers, there were plenty of advantages in hiring younger rather than older women that compensated for the risk of the employee becoming pregnant.

body_text.text: On the other hand, younger women, many of them highly educated, were eager to stay in employment even after the birth of a child to make the most of career opportunities that were much more exciting than in the pre-transition period.

body_text.text: As for child-care provision, while it dramatically decreased during the 1990s and its cost soared, this was much less the case for nurseries, which were very few even before transition.

body_text.text: In general, child care was not adequate before transition and was less widespread than in other countries of the former Socialist Block, especially in rural areas.

body_text.text: Concluding remarks

In this article we have analyzed the relationship between motherhood and employment probabilities of Polish women before and during transition using panel data for the periods of 1987-1989 and 1994 -1996.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: Before transition, despite the very high female participation in employment, Polish mothers -especially mothers of young children -were substantially less likely to work than childless women.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: During transition, to our surprise, the negative effect of motherhood was substantially lower than in the pre-transition period.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: In the multivariate analysis, a significant coefficient was estimated only for mothers of children aged 0-2 years old and even in this case the average population effect turned out to be much smaller than in the pre-transition period.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: This result goes in the opposite direction to what one would have expected, based on the common notions of very high female labour market participation in the communist Poland, sustained by the existence of family-friendly policies and a publicly-funded affordable network of child-care facilities, which were dismantled during transition, making women's participation in employment theoretically more difficult.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: Our findings are not driven by a change in the association of the 'taste for children' and the 'taste for employment' in the two periods, because our estimates -obtained with CRE panel probit models -control for unobserved heterogeneity in the two samples.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: The most plausible interpretation is that, before transition, in absence of constraints in accessing the labour market, women could realize their preferences for lower employment in coincidence of motherhood or were 'forced' out of work by the expectations of a traditional society that required mothers (especially of very young children) to be the primary caretakers of their children.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: At the same time, although child-care services were much more affordable before than during transition, in the pre-1989 Poland availability of child care was already a problem, especially for very young children and in the rural areas of the country.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: On the other hand, during transition, the uncertainty in the labour market, the process of restructuring, the necessity of relying on two earners in the household, the need (and desire) of not being cut out of new job opportunities in the growing private sector, and the gloomy perspective of long-term unemployment after a prolonged period out of the labour market could have represented more powerful 'pushing' factors for women to work than the disincentive produced by the deterioration of child-care facilities.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: This is not to say that women were not experiencing growing difficulties in combining paid work and family responsibilities, © 2009 The Authors Journal compilation © 2009 The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development nor that this conflict was without potentially negative consequences for women's employment.
body_text.section: Concluding remarks

body_text.text: It rather stresses how powerful were constraints other than the decrease in child-care availability (many of them on the demand-side) in shaping women's employment opportunities during transition.
